document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Science

EE3C0135588F4F978EF9C5C98393805A.description:
Actively engage in an activity that demonstrates
movement and effects of a glacier. Push a large ice cube
across a container of sand, dirt and pebbles, to recognize
that ice blocks (glaciers) can move materials. Push down
to make the ice cube dig a hole in the sand, relate this to
the formation of the Great Lakes.

A3097079AA2042BD88AF27F254B2C8B0.description:
Look at a series of pictures from around Ohio, sort them
into glaciated and unglaciated areas.

6202F53F283F4BD28BEF56AC1685F7C5.description:
Use pictures to identify the different kinds of glaciers (e.g.,
valley, piedmont, glaciers, cirque, tidewater).

227F7F2690284D83B0AE47BB4FC7C95F.description:
Identify features on a map that are a direct result of
glaciation (e.g., the Great Lakes, glacial grooves on
Kelleys Island).

AF8CCCB4EEDF41FA853B5E658A0C3026.description:
Use a map to trace the movement of glaciers globally for
the last 20 years.

38E106432F074CC0AFD85FE26B3C2FA4.description:
Identify
that glaciers
consist mainly of
ice.

80C813B7F3F944C19F516C8910385DF1.description:
Identify
land features in Ohio
that were formed by
glaciers.

5C9347668F9E4357B83A240A02C33FC8.description:
Describe land
features that were
formed through
either erosion or
deposition from
glaciers.

5371802EA0AB4D9FBCC575AF326958B9.description:
Glaciers and
glaciation
• Evidence of past glaciers
(including features
formed through erosion or
deposition)
• Glacial deposition and
erosion (including features
formed through erosion or
deposition)
• Data from ice cores
• Historical changes
(glacial ages, amounts,
locations, particulate
matter, correlation to fossil
evidence)
• Evidence of climate
changes throughout Earth’s
history
• Glacial distribution and
causes of glaciation
• Types of glaciers:
continental (ice sheets,
ice caps), alpine/valley
(piedmont, valley, cirque, ice
caps)
• Glacial structure, formation,
and movement

848D0A2BC4C24FE2BD2C1618872E7D07.description: Examine before and after images of erosion.

0E813E849D034C29AB9D1E40E254504F.description: Recognize a landform or area that resulted from erosion.

B829CCA28933403B8D245F2B8049700B.description:
Define
erosion as the
movement of
Earth’s materials.

704572D957A440349DF7BDB194C32719.description:
Describe how
erosion can
change an
environment.

1649F9FEA503462BBD90D134ADCBC0C9.description:
Soil and sediment
• Desertification
• Mass wasting and erosion
• Sediment contamination

3B412567129148EE835765D376B3D01B.description:
Actively participate in a discussion about water that is
good for drinking versus water that would not be.

86DC6A76751D4407B7B540BCB57790C8.description: Recognize that some water is potable and some is not.

BF416DD112E14B6B9BB41F3D42898BFA.description:
Recognize that the water used for drinking has to be
processed to be used.

9D1EC6C2D5E04222A974A463AE5CF181.description: In your region, identify where your water originates.

E7447B9D04844269BD750B393F3135B5.description:
Describe characteristics of potable and nonpotable water
or factors that make it potable/non potable.

BE04B7036BC74F87BDE93FE8104BE70F.description: Sort water sources as potable and nonpotable.

6282F8531EA240048FDF967F7FD4A2C8.description:
Describe why it is
important to have
clean drinking
water.

6487DA8EA8DF4A9D9A9F5C401F076584.description:
Water
• Potable water and water
quality
• Hypoxia, eutrophication

682465F07D6A43809A5EE274DA2DA0F4.description: Engage with the air by taking a deep breath and exhaling.

9DF967CBBD734C34AB703F427013E9B7.description:
Recognize when there is a change in the air (hot, cold,
odor, scent, humid).

0C074ECDEBB842A1A5A427C338459EA1.description: Identify an effect of a primary and secondary contaminant.

D5FC022246EF4B9181491B8D9F68A814.description:
Use Google Earth to view a local area to determine what
exists in an area and what products are produced and how
that impacts an area (e.g., farms, housing developments,
industries, nature reserves).

C1BAAA6F2D74470B938EF06E95CD7741.description:
Identify greenhouse gases (e.g., carbon dioxide, water
vapor) and how they can impact the atmosphere and
environment.

01C76AED757E432EB7BCD3AA58205966.description:
Identify a
cause and effect of
specific air pollution
problem (e.g., smoke
from a factory causes
haze in the air).

B44618315B7A425A9C179442713C5406.description:
Describe how
greenhouse
gas effects the
atmosphere.

8DB93291E88646F8A9BBCB2ABE058BCF.description:
Air
• Primary and secondary
contaminants
• Greenhouse gases

8A3C25F8F7854A25874C9BB7767911B9.description:
Recognize that minerals are used in our everyday
materials.

1D47E473105D474BB119FB400AFB6486.description: Recognize that minerals are extracted through mining.

634839F0C6604FDABC837F0B050013FD.description: Recognize that minerals are a nonrenewable resource.

AB2557F2FF3B4F628D18C549249C56D4.description:
Understand that nonrenewable means that once it is used
there is no way to get more in a reasonable time frame.

F167FFE28150478EA35862CC5354775A.description:
Understand that renewable means more can be made is a
short period of time.

8E7522D7EF3648E086CE9600BFADEB08.description:
Provide pictures of mining sites and describe the changes
to the environment. Describe how those changes impact
wildlife.

62A30CAE8A50482D999632F13AFCEB43.description:
Recognize that
minerals are a
resource.

2D911A9D93334A45984B088FE2572EAF.description:
Identify the
effect that mining for a
mineral resource has
on an area.

F4E5F813C5EB41ABBC698C10CAC25185.description:
Identify
factors to consider
before mining for
mineral resources
(e.g., cost,
pollution, effects
on wildlife).

9F334B426317419EA97A03DAE23789AD.description:
Energy resources
• Renewable and
nonrenewable energy
sources and efficiency
• Alternate energy sources
and efficiency
• Resource availability
• Mining and resource
extraction

47366E4E4A7C482CAC9AEF2BFADE50BB.description:
Watch a video of a flower blooming or a glacier moving
in real time and in fast motion, recognize that sometimes
movement is too slow to see.

F4E356090C1E4E88BFA329AE48E0D679.description:
Identify the name of the previous supercontinent as
Pangaea.

09522AF4FFC3463EAD61805A057A9715.description: Recognize that the surface of Earth has changed.

771B1E36DEB94784924F7DC349E1048D.description:
Review maps of Earth’s continents over the past 300,000
years to identify changes.

78F6281742ED4BC697FD9D6A6D1E42F7.description:
Use cut outs of the modern continents, try to fit them
together like a puzzle, understand that the fact they fit is
evidence they were once joined.

F3F41243B1A54484BBBD517D905E7910.description:
Recognize that plate motion has caused the continents to
shift. Use video footage of Hawaii to illustrate this type of
activity.

4D5E127C6F204981AD813C1D32D8BB52.description:
Identify
the crust as the
location of the
continental plates.

340B84C3C1CD44CFA543FFD1FC9A155E.description:
Recognize
that the shape of the
continents is evidence
of plate motion (e.g.,
they fit together like
puzzle pieces).

7BEA054B865F49D0B506E45A3E7E85B6.description:
Describe
how the continents
used to be
connected in one
super continent
of Pangaea and
have moved due to
tectonic forces.

9BA1F81948594DDE9042E47163CDC14B.description:
Plate motion (Note:
introduced in grade 8)
• Causes and evidence of
plate motion
• Measuring plate motion
• Characteristics of oceanic
and continental plates
• Relationship of plate
movement and geologic
events and features
• Mantle plumes

F1E473EF168B4832B77B87E68D104897.description:
Complex and advanced learning standards in Ohio’s New
Learning Standards are not included in the extended
standards.

24E96A677DE44471965F119A0AA3F143.description:
Historical review
(Note: this would include a
review of continental drift and
sea-floor spreading found in
grade 8)
• Paleomagnetism and
magnetic anomalies
• Paleoclimatology

5DB2932CB3A94DB6B709876EED4EAF83.description:
Complex and advanced learning standards in Ohio’s New
Learning Standards are not included in the extended
standards.

A353D7C2CD7F42EB8387DF3B3A47991E.description:
Structure of Earth
(Note: specific layers were
part of grade 8)
• Asthenosphere
• Lithosphere
• Mohorovičić (Moho)
boundary
• Composition of each of the
layers of Earth
• Gravity, magnetism and
isostasy
• Thermal energy (geothermal
gradient and heat flow)

582C432AA6D945ACBB4EBBCCB2FDE8EF.description: Watch video footage of small and large earthquakes.

A2B760AA6ACE482CAC52320155DBCDF9.description: Recognize that earthquakes have different strengths.

F45A7AEE5D1E4EB29ABBD6986591C348.description:
Recognize that the Richter scale uses numbers to
describe the strength of earthquakes (larger numbers are
10 times stronger than the number before).

D16B1483C4454063BF27B38952F6EFAA.description:
Compare seismograms, recognize that large “wiggles”
mean more shaking of the ground.

7AE7BAD9F10F434583FA8943217326A4.description:
Given two seismograms choose the one that represents a
stronger earthquake.

A460472BB1F642359EF4C328FE2CDF11.description:
Recognize that the “wiggles” on the seismograph
represents energy waves traveling through Earth.

EEC20D1A0FA34EFD9563A1B6CA73D589.description:
Recognize that
a Richter scale
is a tool used to
measure intensity
of earthquakes.

CD6E4034FBF948549035FB4C32B3174D.description:
Describe
how a Richter scale
is used as a tool
to measure the
seismic waves of an
earthquake.

91C4A864230E4D15AC1228D8265842AC.description:
Analyze which
earthquake was
larger based on
a seismographic
report or readout.

CBB8A2AD7D1F457BA647C10512F7D761.description:
Internal Earth
• Seismic waves
• S and P waves
• Velocities, reflection,
refraction of waves

0BEA022B5F974045AF1ACF0B6254DA95.description:
Engage with a model of a cross section of a highway cut
or rock layers.

953BA5D407ED440589E64034FCE5BE27.description:
Identify the layers that can be seen within a cross section
(e.g., highway cut, Grand Canyon).

D1EFE70B3892488BBF02F128978E804E.description:
Model the formation of rock layers and relate the age of
the layers to the Law of Superposition.

DA52C4E90DD94B638DDD16AE18A4BE7F.description:
Given a cross section of rock determine the relative age in
an undisturbed section.

7C48A5147D0B4F02805D2A695A3C5C4B.description:
Recognize that there are a variety of methods to
determine the age of rock.

3DBE1150E709455FB575AD48959A8772.description:
Explain that radiometric dating traces radioactive materials
in the rock to determine age.

A1422984F5514D408D9D828F4ED3CBAC.description:
Identify
changes across
layers (crosssection) of rocks.

1A5E07BDEFA145DAB09606A936DC8468.description:
Identify
that in a cross-section
of rock, the layer on
top is the youngest
layer and the layer
on the bottom is the
oldest (assuming no
geological process
has shifted the
layers).

95DDF793AE2944FCA6EB5C8282FCBCA3.description:
Describe how
technology assists
in determining the
age of rocks (e.g.,
radiometric dating).

54FF4B1326C24702A39C6487C004DA21.description:
The geologic rock
record
• Relative and absolute age
• Principles to determine
relative age
• Original horizontality
• Superposition
• Cross-cutting relationships
• Absolute age
• Radiometric dating
(isotopes, radioactive
decay)
• Correct uses of radiometric
dating
• Combining relative and
absolute age data
• The geologic time scale
• Comprehending geologic
time
• Climate changes evident
through the rock record
• Fossil record

4E8AD59420B64186B7D01B0568A81E95.description:
Engage by watching convection in a tub of water to
observe how temperature differences make water move in
currents (heat a tub of water under one side only, sprinkle
in pepper and watch the circulation pattern).

C7B8BEED37354A67A3DDB458DC52633D.description:
Recognize that tides are controlled by the gravitational
attraction between the moon and Earth.

B79D2C7E8439416B9B8152459BB1645F.description:
View time lapse videos of tides in the ocean, recognize
that the water level changes due to the tides.

CFE328B8C4E548319DBE63FE73D55389.description:
Watch videos on ocean currents (e.g., NASA, NOAA, Bill
Nye) to look at patterns; understand that ocean currents
move materials around the ocean and affect the climate
on Earth.

2768FCA7C9804BE28F3E4635172F35FB.description:
Given a tide table, identify the pattern (amount of time)
that occurs between high and low tide and high tide to
next high tide.

18A49924B5654110A490611F5BD6A441.description:
Identify
a reason for a
change in sea
level.
(e.g., tides,
currents, waves,
etc.).

74FCC51D01DF43BDBB2631776D7DE9D2.description:
Describe
how the tides are
controlled by the
moon.

712A124155BC4A9882901C4640C8E2C7.description:
Use
data to see how
the sea level
changes with the
tides in a given
location.

C175F99759C14F20A1418950CF38FD5F.description:
Ocean
• Tides (daily, neap, and
spring)
• Currents (deep and shallow,
rip and longshore)
• Thermal energy and water
density
• Waves
• Ocean features (ridges,
trenches, island systems,
abyssal zone, shelves,
slopes, reefs, island arcs)
• Passive and active
continental margins
• Transgressing and
regressing sea levels
• Streams (channels,
streambeds, floodplains,
cross-bedding, alluvial fans,
deltas)

03BA535912E14D2395104D678981200E.description:
Build a model of the formation of sedimentary rock (e.g.,
shake sand and dirt in a jar of water, let it sit and describe
what happens (settles to the bottom), relate this to
sediments falling to the bottom of an ocean).

395C197C83E347E0B5D8BB499EBDE052.description:
Describe locations where sedimentary rocks can form
(e.g., desserts, oceans).

6AD1FF84527F4691B48E0773DD72CD2B.description:
Predict what would happen if lots of pressure squeezed
the sediments (they would cement together).

AE4DAE3A93AA45AFAB073566E8CBC6BE.description:
Identify
environments in
which sedimentary
rocks are formed.

9A0286B5D66B4E2BB073D377CD55919C.description:
Describe
the properties of
sedimentary rocks.

172C1EFDA48B49EE88138795D125F4C1.description:
Compare
how different
environments
change the type of
sedimentary rock
that is formed.

4F7550BFFA994068BBC371EBEBFDFA66.description:
Sedimentary
• Division of sedimentary
rocks and minerals
(chemical, clastic/physical,
organic)
• Depositional environments

40EA6B7C76A247419996B71B04973CC2.description:
Recognize that heat and pressure cause things to change.
(e.g., examine a slice of white bread (crust removed),
describe its properties, roll and squish it into a small ball,
describe how its properties have changed, relate this to
metamorphic rocks changing from other existing rocks
(heat and pressure from your hand).

CCEBDB7A34874BCDAB0D46C21643FD2A.description:
Look at samples of metamorphic rocks and the rocks
they formed from (e.g., slate from shale, marble from
limestone), note the differences and similarities

43C56CE8F35C41B5B240671E29AF58E5.description:
Identify
environments in
which metamorphic
rocks are formed.

B6F00C776D5D4F3D8B0936EEBE9A9FC7.description:
Describe
the properties of
metamorphic rocks.

AEF5E02D88D4470BA4263077277C77DC.description:
Compare
how different
environments
change the type of
metamorphic rock
that is formed.

F44E5F53A0FC4EC4A0577737BD532401.description:
Metamorphic
• Pressure, stress,
temperature, and
compressional forces
• Foliated (regional), nonfoliated (contact)
• Parent rock and degrees of
metamorphism
• Metamorphic zones (where
metamorphic rocks are
found)

0C1A7DA750B84995BEB1FDDF36274F2C.description:
Recognize that the cooled lava from volcanoes forms
igneous rock (e.g., Hawaii).

F87A90E9AB01428BB7E0F0905612F26C.description:
View images or videos of volcanoes at various locations
(e.g., edges of continents, mid-ocean spreading centers,
hotspots).

AC510F5D7BF1487FA33E345C5ADC7ADC.description:
Identify that granite makes up much of continental crust
and basalt makes up much of our ocean floors.

5F38854AC04649C7BF5BF5C7776F0427.description:
Look at samples of igneous rock (e.g., granite, basalt),
identify differences and recognize that they were formed in
different environments.

38D95C2A4DEB49AD9E56B976C1D2CA7E.description:
Identify
environments in
which igneous
rocks are formed.

9D89B1BE026348C18BCA564371DA3B38.description:
Describe
the properties of
igneous rocks.

8EB5D083494B40A3883DBC92A0351A46.description:
Compare
how different
environments
change the type of
igneous rock that
is formed.

7FDE93E558EE401FB658EA1C6A097845.description:
Igneous
• Mafic and felsic rocks and
minerals
• Intrusive (igneous
structures: dikes, sills,
batholiths, pegmatites)
• Earth’s interior (inner core,
outer core, lower mantle,
upper mantle, Mohorovičić
[Moho] discontinuity, crust)
• Magnetic reversals and
Earth’s magnetic field
• Thermal energy within Earth
• Extrusive (volcanic activity,
volcanoes: cinder cones,
composite, shield)
• Bowen’s Reaction
Series (continuous and
discontinuous branches)

6436F342451A4AEE90735C9AC0EB5D93.description: Engage with rocks by feeling the surface of each.

D58687265DC54C71B6529BE81F9C95F7.description:
Manipulate rocks to identify textural characteristics of
each.

DE432C59403A479DA66ACCA7109EF64F.description:
Match a sample rock to its origin given a set of
characteristics (e.g., using pictures, maps, illustrations,
etc.).

634B986553814BA1A38CAF83F485FF8E.description:
Investigate a sample rock and determine its identity by
testing its properties.

9FF712611F324AA58C9CB14FBBC8353E.description:
Match
minerals by
properties (e.g.,
cleavage, streak,
magnetism).

956E99F0FE5D4D5593C9D8A5B9445391.description:
Identify
hardness and fracture
as two characteristics
to identify a mineral.

9CF649A504FA44D5ADC569F4353C496B.description:
Sort
minerals by
cleavage, streak,
hardness and
fracture.

D6FB7185DFB44B84A0DFD05F8838CCB5.description:
Properties of minerals
(hardness, luster, cleavage,
streak, crystal shape,
fluorescence, flammability,
density/specific gravity,
malleability)

3AEFC8BA365744A0B5DD93E80B749718.description:
Watch videos that show how minerals are formed in a
variety of rocks.

A6BFAEA3566E46999C89A63D21587F11.description:
Examine a variety of rocks and note the size of the
crystals in the structure.

0B6B1B572CDD4A4894C75B64E6B92A80.description: Use a crystal growing kit to illustrate how crystals form.

6B7B7E6114DF419683C1E914B72847D4.description:
Recognize that
minerals can be
found in rocks.

6AB4B876E81F43BDB598634FD698F908.description:
Identify a
common mineral in a
common rock.

ECB403447C37411585F49B45C1BD9D67.description:
Match
minerals with rock
types in which
they are commonly
found.

4D5FB1F8F2C84F4590E209639BBA10D4.description:
Criteria of a mineral
(crystalline solid, occurs in
nature, inorganic, defined
chemical composition)

6E5B452414ED44389499E33738FC1CE4.description:
Complex and advanced learning standards in Ohio’s New
Learning Standards are not included in the extended
standards.

26711F6EFC264313A6F4953ED539C9D8.description:
Engage with a model of an atom to locate the valence
(outermost) electrons.

FF5164FE2E0D4E1EB0D871C382FC3294.description:
Recognize that valence electrons are in the outside layer
of an atom.

93FF01F0FA854D9281760570FDC46E6C.description:
Identify the valence electrons on a drawing or model on an
atom.

927D1DF58014468C98C70070C774F2AE.description:
Recognize that an atom’s reactivity is based on its valence
electrons.

7ACD27F747124380B8C3F9E720507125.description:
Identify common minerals that are bonded ionically and
covalently.

5E6313E9769841CF893B951FD51E4B98.description:
Recognize that in covalent bonding atoms share valence
electrons so that each have 8.

5F5C049367044EC1A9A75623D673509F.description:
Recognize that ionic bonding is an attraction between
oppositely charged ions.

79912FBD513F47D3AAFB6B29251A7825.description:
Recognize an ion as an atom that has gained or lost
valence electrons (which changes their electrical charge).

F9BD4364ECA142F4934F8D44AE9EB286.description:
Recognize that different atoms react in different ways
(ionic and covalent bonding).

1B842477BAD34699874C5A4BD988E5D5.description:
Use an atomic model and/or video to investigate that
atoms interact to achieve 8 valence electrons (view the
product).

56AA0B6202BC4F2D8CA1CCD350C19768.description:
Identify
that two elements
combine to form a
compound.

E0507642A6BB4DF18165D7F067EF74C4.description:
Recognize
that a model (balland-stick or molecular
geometries) or
chemical formula
represents a chemical
compound.

B921CA54506D4FFAA7E60E9447B6248B.description:
Represent
a chemical
compound with
a ball-and-stick
model or chemical
formula.

44D925AD8C45427CB059FF32DAF0C70F.description:
Engage with models or various visual representations of
an atom.

41BDF27486E643359A0E94AB2DD2F546.description:
Select the diagram that shows an atom from a set of
drawings.

42EC7FC274264442BDBD79BDFB03E236.description:
Place labels (protons, neutrons, electrons) on a drawing of
an atom.

A5F32E193C664DFCA934DE5EEB43CE92.description:
Identify the valence electrons on a drawing or model on an
atom.

B8426BAA6B854058BE553294F85A8C6D.description:
Recognize that valence electrons are in the outside layer
of an atom.

23041BB481E840E78A7C5C77C760FF2E.description:
Identify that protons have a positive charge, neutrons are
neutral, and electrons have a negative charge.

CE693F2B9E7F48EAB5E0A03F75FD3579.description:
Build or recognize a model of an atom including protons,
neutrons or electrons.

C64058F021B54306B25CD8B202035A1F.description:
Identify
that all matter is
made of atoms.

3440F946056242CDAA7AA05026416EC5.description:
Identify a
diagram or model of
an atom.

ADB4E53C2C4F47E79CE82A63CCFDA13E.description:
Identify
parts of an atom
(e.g., protons,
neutrons,
electrons).
